q.q: HUGE musical breakthrough after a year of progress. tell me if i'm onto something here. so there's the feeling of home, familiarity. let's say that's a chord. now that's got certain notes in it, and is either a Major chord, which is good vibes, or Minor, which is usually a feeling of evil or sadness. But whether we're happy or sad, home is home. Now, if our next chord is what we expect it to be, using a lot of the same notes as the first chord, then that's not much of an adventure. but if all of the sudden we're playing very unexpected notes, that can have this otherworldly vibe. i discovered this by playing a D minor chord followed by a B major. because I've already played the D and the F without making it sharp or flat, you really wouldnt expect me to flip it on it's head and make both the D and the F sharp. so it feels like we've learned something new and extraordinary, especially because the B is Major compared to the unhappy minorness of home. a m i gett ing somewhere?

Hi Bill,
My ex-girlfriend and I broke up (we're still good friends though). She said that I became more awkward around her in person and she didn't want to ruin our relationship. I told her that I completely understood, but in all honesty, I hate myself for fucking up what we had together. I don't know why I became so awkward around her in person, and it really irritates me that I messed up with her, because I really did love her. I just didn't want to come off as clingy and weird in public. I'm kind of a shy and quiet person most of the time, and it takes me a while to warm up to someone and show them the real me. The only reason I didn't show her the love and affection that she deserved in public is because we only really see each other in school, and I didn't want anyone looking at me strangely. I get embarrassed and nervous easily, and I would have been panicking in my head if people looked and laughed at me while I was being affectionate t owards h er. The real issue here is that I still have feelings for her. I miss what we had together. I want to try again and be less awkward around her, but I feel like she'll turn me down this time because she might find someone else or I might fuck it up again. I don't know if I'll ever find a girl like her again. I feel like a hopeless piece of shit. What do I do to make myself feel better in a time like this? (sorry for the long ass question btw)

Sincerely Yours, "D"
(p.s. I love your content!)

q.q: hey i asked the ska question from an hour or so ago. man i gotta talk this out, i hope you will listen because it feels important to me and i want to get your thoughts. i used to LOVE ska. streetlight manifesto was probably my first musical love. yet nobody else in my rural community seemed to like them very much. my mom called my music "mariachi music" which upset me, because her deliberate mischaracterization showed me the lack of care she had for what i liked, and that the music didn't resonate with her, so she belittled it.

q.a: find people online who like the same stuff you do. youtube, reddit, many other places
q.q: my dad never jived with it. nor did my siblings. my friends didn't like it at all, either, calling it too manic. so whenever i tried to share this music with anybody i liked i would get frustrated and embarrassed. i eventually stopped listening to it. years later i figured i had just grown out of it, some weird ska phase in my life in my angsty and misguided years. but recently i've been listening to a lot of ska. and i realiz ed, fuck  it, i love this stuff. and everyone else is actually the weird one. this music speaks to me in ways that other music just does not really. i'm pissed that i was talked out of a love of mine. and now that i'm reclaiming this, i'm faced with the same challenge. i want to share this love but i feel so alone.

q.a: that's probably not a good strategy. you have a long lasting personal connection to the music, you can't just make someone have the same connection instantly. everyone is on their own unique musical journey. surely your dad, mom, siblings, all have their own music collections which they feel deeply attached to. do you think they could convince you to suddenly feel what they feel, for their music
q.q: how can i help people i care about feel what this music makes me feel?
i gotta spread this joy or i get irritated

q.q: so i was recording vocals in my living room the other day and i got all these different hums going on. went on the internet and somebody said that those are natural harmonics being produced in nature and that those happen in multiples and you gotta EQ them out.

q.a: that might be true
q.q: so i go to EQ the point that i think the problem is at then i see that there's also a problem with another number, which i can only surmise means that there are also problems with all the multiples of that. i could throw another EQ thing on the track and get rid of those too but i feel like at that point i'm killing the life of the track. so i talked to a dude about this and he said "the acoustics in that room are shitty, those are called standing waves, you can fix that by putting absorber pads on your wall."

q.a: my room is almost entirely carpeted. that helps a lot. if you have a mostly non-carpeted room you are screwed. also there is a lot of stuff in here, which helps. there are pictures on the walls, etc. there is just a lot of stuff in here. there is actually a very small sound absorbing pad that i put on a blank spot on the wall but i think the effects are probably negligible. the sound seems to be ok but i've been noticing more lately that it's not perfect. someone actually once told me they thought i put reverb on the narration vocals on history of japan, but not the jingle vocals. this is backwards, there is no reverb on the narration, but a little bit on the jingles. what this tells me is that the natural room acoustics are audible on the narration because there is much less other music to mask it. but during the jingles, or full musical arrangements, it is not audible

q.a: if it were me i'd just say whole tone with the D flipped out to Db and D# instead, IF those notes you listed were the exact notes i needed. probably a lot of people would say altered but i just think there is ambiguity surrounding those situations, both in the terminology and in the reality. in places where the 'altered' scale is typically used, in your key, it would be like if you're on a C7("alt")(which could mean anything from b9 to #9 to +5) about to go to Fmin. and i think in reality your strongest notes are going to be Db, Eb, Bb, Ab, E, and then i'd say tied for the next lesser level of priority would be like F and G, and furthermore this entire umrella of chord scenarios (the C7"alt" to Fmin) in general is very friendly to dense chromatic passing tones, so the remaining notes will immediately go onto the table. this has included some of the notes not in your scale, and also i might add that i think Gb is least likely to be a good choice, actually quite frankly i don't think Gb would belong in the 'altered' scale, if we're talking about what really is strongest for most of the situations where 'alt' is written in the chord symbol. as you study a lot of tunes from the same time period, same composer, etc., you may notice them consistantly using a certain type of 'dark' V7 chord (C7 going to Fmin, in our key) and 'alt' may seem like a friendly concept within the context of one particular time period or composer, but as you travel from decade to decade you'll notice that the 'typical' scenarios become slightly different, and yet still pronounced. some calling strongly for the C7b9, or others more strongly calling for #9 and +5. just when you think you have found the archetypical type within a certain time period or sector of music, move just a few steps and you will find it's different and yet also seemingly archetypical. but i would like to repeat something i said earlier which is sure you can absolutely call your series of notes by either of the 2 previous names first mentioned in the original question, they are perfectly justified names. but be ready to clarify what notes you want if the person says 'what'
q.q: 3.20.18 3:57 am "C Db, D#, E, Gb, G#, Bb". the same notes as Db melodic minor but starting on C.

q.a: i think this is a common technique when there is a lot of readable content on a shirt. if it's on the front no one will ever be able to fully read it without the wearer patiently watching you read it. when it's on the back it is much more likely to be read, particularly by people waiting/standing in line (in a line, on line, on a line, on a queue, etc) behind the wearer. for example i think those t-shirts with tour schedules always have it on the back because it greatly increases the chances it will be read and studied by strangers, closely enough to make plans to go to the show. if the information were on the front i think it could not be studied carefully without creating a very awkward moment betweenst the viewer and the wearer

q.a: if it's major it is usually called Db, because that's less degrees in the key signature. but in a loud room, it might be better to verbally say "C#" because if you say Db they might think you said Bb
q.q: How come almost everyone would say that a song is in the key of C# instead of the key of Db,

q.a: right, that's because D# major spelled out properly with letters would have to be D#, E# Fx(double sharp), G#, A#, B#, and Cx(double sharp)
q.q: but the key of Eb as opposed to the key of D# seems to be the norm,

q.a: F# and Gb are equivalent choices because they each have 6 degrees in the key signature, but it may be more often called F# for two reasons. one is kind of like the C#/Db case where F# is more verbally clear in a crowded room, but also it is more common for keys to borrow flatter notes than sharper ones. which creates no problems at all in F# where as in Gb it immediately creates double flats. actually i can think of a 3rd reason. F# as a note would be much more common than Gb because F# is the first note to go, in sharp keys. where as in flat keys Gb is is the 5th note to go. so people are already more accustomed to verbally hearing the words "F#" than Gb
q.q: or F# instead of Gb etc?

the concept of dividing by 0 being 'undefined' has always made sense to me. like, on an intuitive level. today i was trying to explain it to someone who was confused by this property, and despite my best efforts, they just didn't get it. but now i'm wondering if i'm the one who misunderstood it. i'm gonna attempt to explain it to u, because i know you understand math. and maybe u can tell me if there's a flaw in my explanation/understanding.
to divide a number by x, you split it into x many pieces. 8/2=4, because each of the two equal pieces of eight = four. or, 8/5=1.6, because each of the five equal pieces of eight = one and six-tenths. so, to get zero equal pieces of eight, you need to find a value that when added zero times = eight. and there isn't a value like that.
do u think that makes sense (how i said it)?

q.q: 3.8.18 8:27 pm If you divide by a number less than one, it's a multiplication (in essence). Dividing 2 by 1/2 is 4, by 1/3 is 6, etc. In other words, the smaller the fraction, the higher the multiplication. Extrapolating, you can see that dividing by zero is (abstractly) the same as multiplying by infinity. So dividing by zero doesn't give you a real answer because infinity is an abstract concept (whereas numbers are abstract concepts that can have sort-of tangible real-life equivalents). q.a:
for reality: 1. i need to search through thousands of hours to find and put together clips that are good. 2. need to make video for them 3. the more time has passed since the original recording date, the more opportunity i have to use stronger foreshadowing, and include things that are much more meaningful, and relate so much stronger to future events
for notes: i didn't have this website when i made the majority of the good stuff, and it's taken a while to get up the courage to post some of the deeper crazier stuff. in the time since 2014, i've mainly just been writing things for twitter, and i do include some of that stuff on the notes page, but people tend to complain that it's too short (twitter has a length limit, so it's fine for twitter and those were written for twitter) and they make a good point. they are for twitter. so i'm not really concerned with those. generally when it comes to much longer notes, that was mostly an outlet to express creativity while i was still figuring out how to actually record full blown songs, with lyrics, with vocals, with all instruments, and with video, all entirely by myself. now that i know how to do that, that is where i spend most of my time. but there are still hundreds, perhaps thousands (depending on how you divide it) of note items which i am releasing gradually, all dated according to when it was written, as always. there are probably 10x as many notes now as there were in 2014, even if you only count the ones before 2014

q.a: blender was the first one that was recommended to me, and it was the first one i tried. i was very impressed with it at first, but i realized something shocking and i had to leave. and i am still puzzled by it, on an existential level, even though i don't use it. here's what happens: when you export something to video, there is no dialog box to name it, and it overwrites previous exports if the name is the same. and the name is the same by default. let me explain this again. when you export something, if you just click export, it will export it with the same name as your previous export and replace the previous export. if you want it to not do that, you have to open up a thing, then type a name, and then save. and it will not warn you if the name is the same as another. so if you export many many many different things during your process, which i do and i suspect most people do, you basically would have to remember to open that up every single time and type a new name, AND manually keep some sort of list of all the names you used and make sure you never use the same name twice. That would be like if you had a camera that saved every picture as "picture" by default, and it wiped out any previous picture named 'picture' every time you took a picture without re-naming it. so not only do you have to name your picture every time but you have to remember all the names you've ever used, so as to not risk deleting a picture. i searched and searched and i could not find an explanation for why the program is this way, or just simply how you would go about this without living in a state of mind fucktastrophy. oh and by the way there's no save dialog and it's easy to quit accidentally. so there's that too

q.q: Have you ever used one of those sinks where you turn the tap ever so carefully and slowly, it budges just a tiny bit and water just explodes out of the faucet, spraying everywhere and making a huge mess? Well, that's the story of my life right now. I have so many ideas and directions I want to go with music that I can't get anything done. Like, the other week I was listening to prelude to the afternoon of a faun and I was thinking how I'd love to learn orchestration and arranging and write these beautiful, epic symphonic poems. But I also LOVE prince and p funk and james brown, and I want to just devote my life to making the funkiest music ever. But I'll watch some of your videos and I love your score-writing and how you sync up music and visuals so well and how that's such a powerful tool and it makes me want to learn animation and video-making. But then I listened to some paul simon, and it's like, maybe I just want to get my acoustic guitar and ju st write  some nice songs. Then I'll hear some top 40 radio and it makes me want to write really fun, upbeat, catchy bubblegum-y tunes. But my first love, the thing that made me want to be a musician was blues, and there's always a part of me that just wants to just be a blues guy... I can go on forever and write a novel about the music I want to make, and I'm being pulled in so many different directions. I'll get really motivated to do something, until I have another idea that makes me pull a 360 and want to do something entirely different. I have all these lofty goals and dreams and things I want to accomplish, but I can't stop time and do everything all at once. More than anything I want to be PROLIFIC. I want a vast library of music. But I can't commit to any one thing because nothing stands out above the rest for what direction I want to go, and what I want to devote myself too. My compass is spinning around. I'll sit at the piano or pick up my guitar to write and can't even foc us on on e thing for more than a few minutes. I'll start working on one thing, and then without even thinking, my brain switches gears and I'll be trying to do something entirely different. Every time I turn on that sink to fill my cup, the water gushes all over the place and I drop the cup and it shatters and I'm left with a spray of water everywhere, but no water in my cup to drink (or to give to others to drink). I've taken a page out of your book and have been really serious about documenting and recording every idea so nothing falls through the cracks... But I just don't know what to do next. Do you have any advice you can share with me? I'm about to explode.
